title: fc718260.WordAssSG.001
frontText: How do you access functions in Word?
backText: You access functions by clicking the menu option and then clicking on the icon in the ribbon underneath the menu bar.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.002
frontText: How can you quickly search for text in Word?
backText: Type the search term(s) in the Search box in the title bar.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.003
frontText: How do you open Word's Navigation pane?
backText: Click the View menu option, and then click the Navigation Pane check box in the View ribbon.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.004
frontText: How do you find and replace text using keyboard shortcuts?
backText: Find text by pressing Ctrl+F. Find and replace text by pressing Ctrl+H.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.005
frontText: How do you go to a specific location in a document?
backText: Click the Home menu option, click the down arrow to the right of Find in the Home ribbon, and then click Go To in the drop‐down menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.006
frontText: How do you show hidden formatting in a document?
backText: In the Home ribbon, click the Show/Hide icon that looks like a paragraph mark.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.007
frontText: How can you hide text in a document?
backText: Select the text, right‐click in the selection, click Font in the pop‐up menu, click the Hidden check box in the Font dialog box, and then click OK.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.008
frontText: What name does Word give its basic template?
backText: Normal

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.009
frontText: How can you change the page settings?
backText: Click the Layout menu option, and then click one of the settings icons in the Layout ribbon.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.010
frontText: What is a style?
backText: A style is saved formatting information that you can apply to selected text in a document.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.011
frontText: Why would you use a watermark in a document?
backText: To tell the reader about the status of a document.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.012
frontText: What is Word's native file format?
backText: .docx

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.013
frontText: How can you share a document electronically in Word?
backText: In a Word formatted file attached to an email message, as a PDF file, on a web page, or on a blog.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.014
frontText: Why would you need to inspect a document?
backText: To ensure that you don't share any personal information and that everyone can read the document no matter their accessibility needs and/or Word version.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.015
frontText: How do you replace words that have a specific capitalized letter?
backText: Click the Home menu option, click Replace in the Home ribbon, click the More button, and then click the Match Case check box in the Find And Replace dialog box.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.016
frontText: How do you add a symbol in a document quickly?
backText: Click the Insert menu option, click the Symbol icon in the Insert ribbon, and then click one of the symbols in the drop‐down menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.017
frontText: How do you apply formatting from one block of text to another quickly?
backText: Use Format Painter.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.018
frontText: How do you make a line of text double‐spaced?
backText: Click the Home menu option, click the Line And Paragraph Spacing icon in the ribbon, and then select 2.0 in the drop‐down menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.019
frontText: How can you open the Styles list using a keyboard shortcut?
backText: Press Ctrl+Alt+Shift+S.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.020
frontText: What are the seven types of page breaks that you can add in a document?
backText: Page, Column, Wrapping, Next Page, Continuous, Even Page, and Odd Page.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.021
frontText: How do you add a table to a document?
backText: Click the Insert menu option, click Table in the Insert ribbon, and then select the number of rows and columns in the grid.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.022
frontText: How do you add a table with its own built‐in styles quickly?
backText: Click the Insert menu option, click Table in the Insert ribbon, move the mouse pointer over Quick Tables in the drop‐down menu, and then click the table style in the side menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.023
frontText: What is a common reason for sorting a table?
backText: To sort the first letters of text in a column in alphabetical order.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.024
frontText: What does it mean to sort in descending order?
backText: To sort the first letters of text in a column from Z to A.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.025
frontText: How can you change the width of a table column on a page quickly?
backText: Move the mouse pointer over the right side of the column boundary until the pointer changes to a double‐headed arrow, and then click and drag the boundary.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.026
frontText: How do you change a table cell width and height precisely?
backText: Click in the cell, click the Layout menu option to the right of the Table Design option, and then set the height and width in the Cell Size section in the ribbon.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.027
frontText: Why would you merge cells in a table?
backText: Because there is too much text in one cell, and it's easier to read the text in two or more combined cells.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.028
frontText: How do you resize a column or table quickly?
backText: Use AutoFit.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.029
frontText: How do you split a table?
backText: Put the cursor in the row where you want to split the table, click the Layout menu option to the right of the Table Design option, and then click the Split Table option in the Layout ribbon.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.030
frontText: Why would you need to add a repeating row header?
backText: If you have a table that's longer than one page, and you want to have the header row at the top of every page for easy reference.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.031
frontText: What is the main feature of a bulleted list?
backText: Each entry in the list starts with a special character, such as a black circle.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.032
frontText: How do you add a numbered list quickly?
backText: Type 1, a period, press the spacebar, and then type your text. After you press Enter, Word converts the text to a numbered list.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.033
frontText: How do you change a bullet list character?
backText: Click the Home menu option. In the Home ribbon, click the down arrow to the right of the Bullets icon, and then click the tile with the character you wish to insert from the drop‐down list.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.034
frontText: How many levels can you create in a list?
backText: Nine

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.035
frontText: How do you reset an entry in a numbered list back to 1?
backText: Right‐click in the entry in the numbered list, and then click Restart At 1 in the context menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.036
frontText: What is a footnote?
backText: A note of reference, explanation, or a comment placed at the bottom of a page.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.037
frontText: What's the difference between a footnote and endnote?
backText: A footnote is at the bottom of the page, but an endnote appears at the end of the document.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.038
frontText: How do you add a footnote?
backText: Place the cursor on the page where you want to add the footnote, click the References menu option, and then click Insert Footnote in the References ribbon.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.039
frontText: How do you delete a footnote or endnote?
backText: Select the superscript number that's connected to the footnote or endnote, and then press Delete on your keyboard.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.040
frontText: What is a bibliography?
backText: The history, identification, or description of writings or publications used when creating a document.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.041
frontText: Why do you need to set a writing style before you create a bibliography?
backText: Because the type of writing style determines how your bibliography appears when you add it to a document.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.042
frontText: How do you add a citation to a bibliography?
backText: Click the References menu option, click Insert Citation in the References menu ribbon, and then click the source in the drop‐down list.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.043
frontText: Why would you need to add a citation placeholder?
backText: Because you're waiting for someone to send you a source that you need to add later, but you don't want to wait for that source to arrive.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.044
frontText: What are the two types of reference tables?
backText: A table of contents (TOC) and a bibliography.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.045
frontText: Where does a table of contents usually appear?
backText: At the beginning of a document.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.046
frontText: What does Word do when it creates a TOC?
backText: Word scans all text with Heading styles and adds text with those styles to the TOC along with their corresponding page numbers.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.047
frontText: How many levels does a TOC have?
backText: Nine

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.048
frontText: How do you remove a TOC?
backText: Click anywhere in the TOC, click the down arrow to the right of the page icon that appears above the TOC, and then click Remove in the menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.049
frontText: Why do you need to update a table?
backText: Word doesn't automatically update page numbers or new text with Heading styles that you added after you created the TOC.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.050
frontText: How do you quickly add a bibliography after you select the writing style guide?
backText: Click Bibliography in the References menu ribbon, and then click one of the three bibliography styles in the drop‐down menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.051
frontText: How do you add a shape into a document?
backText: Click the Insert menu option, click Shapes in the Insert menu ribbon, and then select the shape icon in the drop‐down menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.052
frontText: What sources can you use for a picture to add into a document?
backText: Pictures stored on your computer, as stock images that were installed with Word, and the Office.com website.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.053
frontText: How do you add a picture to a document?
backText: Place the cursor where you want to add the picture, and then click the Insert menu option. In the Insert menu ribbon, click the type of image you want from the drop‐down menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.054
frontText: What does 3D stand for?
backText: Three‐dimensional.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.055
frontText: After you add a 3D model, where does the model appear?
backText: At the location of the cursor in the document and in front of the rest of the text.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.056
frontText: What is a SmartArt graphic?
backText: A graphic that conveys specific types of information, such as an organization chart.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.057
frontText: Where do you choose a SmartArt graphic?
backText: By selecting a graphic in one of the eight categories in the SmartArt Graphic dialog box.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.058
frontText: What is a screenshot?
backText: A screenshot is a photo of your entire screen or a component in it, such as a window.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.059
frontText: What is a screen clipping?
backText: An area of your screen that you can specify by clicking and dragging the mouse pointer over the area of the screen that you want to clip.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.060
frontText: Text boxes are used for what common application?
backText: Creating a sidebar on the left or right side of the document.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.061
frontText: How do you draw your own custom text box?
backText: Click the Insert menu option, click Text Box in the Insert menu ribbon, and then click Draw Text Box at the bottom of the drop‐down menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.062
frontText: How many artistic effects can you apply to a picture at one time?
backText: One

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.063
frontText: How do you add a picture style quickly?
backText: Click the image and then click the Picture Format menu option. In the Picture Format ribbon, click the style icon that you want.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.064
frontText: How do you remove a background color from a picture?
backText: Click the picture, and then click the Picture Format menu option. In the Picture Format ribbon, click Remove Background.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.065
frontText: Where do you change the format of a shape?
backText: In the Shape Format menu ribbon.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.066
frontText: How can you format a picture in the Picture Format ribbon?
backText: Adjust the picture settings, apply picture styles, and change the picture size.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.067
frontText: How can you edit screenshots and screen clippings in the Picture Format ribbon?
backText: Edit points in the shape (that is, the screenshot or screen clipping), set the styles, and change the size of the shape.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.068
frontText: How do you type text in a SmartArt graphic?
backText: Click each [Text] placeholder in the graphic and then type your text.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.069
frontText: How can you change a SmartArt graphic?
backText: By clicking the SmartArt Design menu option and then making changes in the SmartArt Design ribbon.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.070
frontText: How do you rotate a 3D model?
backText: By clicking and dragging the Rotate icon in the center of the model.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.071
frontText: How do you format text in a text box?
backText: Just as you would with any other text in the document.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.072
frontText: How do you rotate the text in a text box 90 degrees?
backText: Click in the text box, click the Shape Format menu option, click Text Direction in the Shape Format ribbon, and then click Rotate All Text 90° in the drop‐down menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.073
frontText: How do you add text to a shape?
backText: Right‐click anywhere in the shape, and then click Add Text in the context menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.074
frontText: How do you place text in a shape so that the text appears vertically aligned at the top of the shape?
backText: Click the Shape Format menu option, click Text Alignment in the Shape Format ribbon, and then click Top in the drop‐down menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.075
frontText: How do you move a shape or image in small increments?
backText: Click on the shape, hold down the Ctrl key, and then press one of the arrow keys to move the shape around.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.076
frontText: How do you select several shapes to move at once?
backText: Hold down the Ctrl key and click each shape that you want to move. Next, right‐click one of the selected shapes and/or images, and then click Group in the context menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.077
frontText: What is wrapping text?
backText: Telling Word to push text around a shape or image in the document.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.078
frontText: What are the seven wrapping text styles?
backText: In Line With Text, Square, Tight, Through, Top And Bottom, Behind Text, and In Front Of Text.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.079
frontText: What are the three wrapping styles that let you set specific wrapping settings?
backText: Square, Tight, and Through.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.080
frontText: What is Alt text?
backText: Alternative text that describes the shape or image.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.081
frontText: How much Alt text should you add?
backText: One or two sentences.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.082
frontText: What do you do to tell Word that a shape or image doesn't need Alt text?
backText: Click the Mark As Decorative check box in the Alt Text pane.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.083
frontText: How do you add a comment to a document?
backText: Place the cursor in the document where you want to add the comment, click the Review menu option, and then click the New Comment icon in the Review menu ribbon.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.084
frontText: Where does Word place comments?
backText: In a margin on the right side of the page outside of the main document.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.085
frontText: How does a comment appear in the document?
backText: In a box with a border color that Word assigns to you.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.086
frontText: What information appears at the top of a comment box?
backText: Your Office username, your avatar (or a placeholder avatar), and how long ago the commenter wrote the comment.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.087
frontText: How do you reply to a comment?
backText: Click Reply in the comment box.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.088
frontText: Why would you want to resolve a comment?
backText: So that people who review the comment can still see it but know that the comment has been resolved.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.089
frontText: How do you resolve a comment?
backText: By clicking Resolve in the lower‐right corner of the comment box.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.090
frontText: What appears in a resolved comment?
backText: Only the commenter name and the first 40 characters (or so) appears in gray text.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.091
frontText: How do you reopen a comment?
backText: By clicking on the resolved comment text in the list and then clicking Reopen in the lower‐right corner of the comment box.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.092
frontText: How do you delete a comment?
backText: Click in the comment box, and then click the Review menu option. In the Review ribbon, click the Delete icon.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.093
frontText: What does the Track Changes feature do?
backText: It shows what changes have been made in a document shared with and reviewed by more than one person.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.094
frontText: How do you turn Track Changes on?
backText: Click the Review menu option, and then click the Track Changes icon in the Review ribbon.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.095
frontText: What are change lines?
backText: Lines that appear in the left margin of the document to alert you that changes have been made in the text.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.096
frontText: How does Word differentiate between reviewers?
backText: Word assigns colors to different reviewers to show who made the changes.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.097
frontText: What is markup?
backText: Formatted text in the document that shows changes, including underlines for added text and strikethrough text for deleted text.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.098
frontText: What are the four types of markup that you can set?
backText: Simple Markup, All Markup, No Markup, and Original.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.099
frontText: How do you accept all tracked changes and turn off Track Changes?
backText: Click the Review menu option. In the Review ribbon, click the Accept text underneath the Accept icon. Finally, click Accept All Changes And Stop Tracking from the drop‐down menu.

title: fc718260.WordAssSG.100
frontText: Why should you lock Track Changes with a password?
backText: So that none of your reviewers can turn off Track Changes without knowing the password.
